[Applause] good morning and thank you for having me here this morning so ironically the only
reason why I came back to Amsterdam back in 2017 is because I changed jobs I left NASA and I started working for a
Hyperloop technology company at my very first business trip was actually to come to Amsterdam because you also have a
local technology company here my background is all engineering aerospace engineering is all my degrees
I worked for NASA for about 16 years and then I left for the private sector specifically to work on the development
of new transportation systems and I decided to do that for a whole variety of reasons the primary one was because I
felt like one of the things I didn't have in my career was any kind of business background business development
sort of customer engagement with people other than very nerdy scientists that I work with at NASA and so it's time for
me to do something else and put my engineering skills to the test but what I will say is that the space program is a very unique environment
where all you do is handle very complicated problems and the challenge with the space program is that you
basically can't use an agile methodology in the traditional sense because when you finally do launch your product it's
pretty much the first time that you're doing it and it has to work the first time so it's slightly different in that sense but in terms of the engineering
skills that go into making something really complicated to come together you can take those lessons learned with you
to wherever you go in your career and so I worked on the development of propulsion systems for about five years for deep-space application with the dawn
mission my show of hands has anyone heard of the dawn mission it's not as familiar but it's a spacecraft that went
to the main asteroid belt to visit two different proto planets and you had to have a very special propulsion system to
get there because it's very far away and that was my PhD thesis topic then I shifted over to work on Mars entry
descent landing systems thank you for the interval on that and then Venus entry descent landing systems and then earth reentry systems and then I did
something from the space station for about five years which ironically has a follow in to quantum computing so I hope
to meet up with the press center over lunch today and that's something called the cold atom laboratory and then I left
to join the private sector to be an executive at a Hyperloop technology company and then I did that for about a
year and a half then I left that to start my own company which is urban air taxi company and so I think
the course of my career I have wanted to work on very challenging things because I find it to be very stimulating and
intellectually challenging and you just get to solve really cool new problems but I think the one thing that bothered
me was that I wasn't really doing anything to help people here at home and I think we all know that one of the
biggest challenges that we have as a species as a planet is climate change and there's a good analog to that by
looking at the neighboring planets so obviously the planet in the middle was earth our home the planet on the left-hand side is Venus which is one
planet in from us and the planet on the right is Mars which is one planet out for us at the formation of our solar
system all of these planets were actually far more similar to each other than they are today which means that over the course the past four and a half
billion years or so these planets have evolved at a planetary level with different types of climate change
phenomena venus which is the one planet in has a surface temperature of 475
degrees centigrade and a surface pressure 100 times the surface pressure on earth and then Mars one planet out
has a surface pressure one percent of Earth and a surface temperature which is quite cold so we really can see by
looking at our neighboring terrestrial planets that indeed climate change is a planetary phenomena and of course both
of the other two planets closest to us we cannot inhabit in the traditional sense because you don't have water on
the surface and you don't have a thinking of atmosphere nor a oxygen based atmosphere to be able to survive
so we can really see that climate change is something that we do need to deal with here at home and I know Europe does
a much better job on that front in terms of shifting over to renewables and the country where I live Los angeles-based
California in the United States obviously we're doing more in our state but across the country we're not doing
enough to address in so that's something which is a challenge for us as a people but my training has always been an

expected so I'm a big fan of engineering because engineering office C is applied science using math and science to
develop new technologies and one of my favorite quotes actually is from the father of modern aerodynamics which is
that basically scientists observe the world as it is and engineers create the world that will be using the tools of
math and science to create new technologies and I think one of the examples of that of course is flight
aerodynamic flight wing borne flight well what is kind of interesting is that there is another very famous scientist
Lord Kelvin a British scientist who invented the Kelvin scale right so huge thermodynamic applications there due to

really complicating when you do something which is sort of like changing the way you think or thinking outside of

that we can make the science fiction world that we see hopefully it's a utopian science fiction world not a
dystopian one a reality using the tools of technology and one of my favorite quotes is in the science fiction Museum
in Seattle I don't remember who it comes from but people who like science fiction are filled with a sense of wonder and
you take that sense of wonder and you translate that to new technologies and so one place where tech new technology
is really important of course is in the mobility sector and you can take a historical look back through time so
back 3,000 BC is when we believe the wheel was invented and so you can
imagine how having the wheel attached to a cart really enabled or transformed human society in terms of moving around
goods and services facilitating people's lives that they could live more comfortably move forward a couple of
thousand years the Industrial Revolution was enabled by the development of basically the Train right and so the
Train allowed you to once again move goods and services at fast speeds over long distances and human society grew as
a result and an economy grew as a result a little forward a couple of decades internal combustion
engine the development of the individual car personal mobility also transformed
human society one could make an argument perhaps it not the best way as a result of the congestion which has come about on ground-based you know roadways today
such as highways and freeways especially where I live in Southern California but nevertheless it did change the way that
we lived so not everybody lived in urban centers people then started to live in the suburbs and further out even into
rural locations using cars to go back and forth move forward a couple of decades letter and the development of
aircraft which enables essentially a connected society global commerce and all of this because of the development
of these transportation technologies so you can really see from a historical context that transportation has
transformed our society and in a way that has grown our economies and probably what we all do today is because
of that if you take a look back at history but of course it does come with this challenges one of the primary ones
of course is congestion on the road which leads to congestion on the air the use of internal combustion engines
whether it is for jet engines or whether it's for cars also has this carbon footprint associated with co2 emissions
so we have that huge environmental challenge which comes from transportation technologies and then from a more sort of geopolitical sense
there are you know when transfers can't be transported properly they said on the ports they sent at airports they sit on
the roads and therefore it actually takes a hit on Commerce so there's money lost the good news is that when you can
save money it's lost all of a sudden you have a business case right so all of a sudden you can start a company which is gonna solve a transportation problem
with new technology greener at the same time and also you'll be able to get investment money because you have a
business case for it which I think it's important in order to be able to do a lot of things that we do as entrepreneurs in this room but one of
the challenges of course though is that NASA transportation has largely been sort of the domain of companies which
have existed for decades or hundreds of years also in the domains at the government's and sometimes you don't get
the same level of innovation which requires you kind of have to have the sort of a disruptive mindset to coming
up with new transportation solutions as opposed to doing more the same and so one of the ways to do that is to think
about it engineering cents I spent many of my years as a systems engineer at NASA which is basically figuring out what the
customer wants and converting it into engineering requirements all the way down to the component level as necessary
so from a transportation system perspective we think about what the customer wants we want to reduce travel
time that's pretty obvious you want to go faster passenger experience nowadays everybody wants to have a good
experience whether it's the way they feel the way they interact with it and of course the environmental impact another one is
capacity how many people do you need to move around per hour per direction between point A and point B or point a
and Point C that's actually very easy to quantify nowadays because of all the data that's come out from even the
survey you just did for example a safety is an important one I think we've all heard in the news issues with the Boeing
737 max any new form of Transportation has to inherently be safer than its predecessors otherwise it just wouldn't
make sense and it's not good engineering if it's not safer cost is also key so transportation and mobility is largely
about public acceptance and public accessibility if the transportation cost is too high the public doesn't have
access to it and therefore it can't be used and so it's really important that whenever we come up with a new transportation system solution is
something which can be implemented all over the world and can also be affordable and that really comes down to an actual engineering constraint because
you have to design something which is affordable and of course the most important one is environmental impact
and so all new technology solutions nowadays especially in this space should focus on that environmental impact so
how does one innovate so this is where I think we all come in which is that doing things differently disrupting actually
requires an entrepreneurial mindset this is where startups could be quite successful and they have been quite successful and even in my you know
two-year journey so far in the private sector in this transportation startup space and I used of course you know
images from I guess what would you call popular culture in the United States in terms of the startup environment but I
think this is very much true it was true for when I worked for a Hyperloop technology company it's true for the Hyperloop technology company that exists
here in the Netherlands which is heart and it's true for my new company which is urban air mobility so when you have a
disconnection from the way things are traditionally done all of a sudden you can see different solutions to this
same problem and you'll be able to innovate in a more interesting way which then comes to the first new interesting
mode of transportation the Hyperloop so when people think about the Hyperloop this is what comes to mind first almost everybody in the United States thinks
Elon Musk invented the Hyperloop and the reality is is that the Hyperloop did come from the domain of science fiction
so if you take a look at science fiction from the 1960s and 1970s the Jetsons for example you saw people traveling in
tubes so once again science fiction providing that sort of like initial innovation kickstart for the rest of us
out there who like the science fiction and in the case of California in the case of Elon Musk the white paper that
was written was written in response to a high-speed rail project which was being
kick-started in the mid-2000s in California and so his argument was that why do high-speed rail it's old
technology why not do something new something more efficient like a Hyperloop that's kind of what brought it to the forefront but it really does have
its origins in science fiction that you can see in these examples here and so the Hyperloop is a great idea I'm
a huge supporter of it I hope it happens in the next you know five to ten years or so and it probably will somewhere in
the world and to describe what the Hyperloop is it is actually a combination of things that already exist
so the primary principle of operation is that you have a maglev train magnetically levitating electrically
propelled traveling through a vacuum tube a vacuum tube basically means you're sucking out all the air when you
suck out all the air you essentially cut down aerodynamic drag to almost zero or for all intensive purposes from an
energy consumption perspective it's zero and if you want to go faster and faster you know drag actually goes with your
speed squared so if you can get rid of that drag force you can actually become very very efficient at high speeds compared to any other mode of
transportation because it's ground-based transportation it can operate off of the grid and if your country's grid comes
from renewables like wind and solar then all of a sudden you can have a transportation solution which is fast
high-speed and environmentally friendly this tube that you see here you can have solar panels on the outside which means
you can even generate your own energy for this fast based transportation over long distances on land masses so it's a
really great transportation system solution and as a result the people who took this up were different startups
from around world the one I worked at was based in Los Angeles we had a test facility where
we built a half kilometre Hyperloop that you can see me standing in front of in the desert just outside of Las Vegas if
you google that on Google Maps you can actually see it's like a long tube and so we use that to demonstrate the
technology so we did use an agile methodology in the sense that we built a you know 70% scale prototype of the
vacuum tube and a vehicle to travel inside of it to demonstrate basically the vacuum operation and the Maglev
aspect of the passenger vehicle there is a test track being built in Toulouse I think there's probably two of them being
built in France now there's a company in Canada a company another company in the United States and then I think you also
have a test track being built here in the Netherlands with Hart which is the other local company so all the companies
working in this space are startups none of them are traditional transportation companies they're partnering with
traditional infrastructure companies for example because a lot of this is related to infrastructure such as laying roads
and bridges and sort of right away but nevertheless all in that startup space
because it's a very disruptive way of doing things but ultimately to drive down the cost you have to come up with
other solutions and so here we can actually take a look at the coupling to the software community the software
industry where that if we can address where are the places in the world that have the writer ship that could make use
of a system like this from going to point A to point C and how do we make it on-demand and that's where you can use
the data that exists of people's current transit patterns optimize it to figure out where is the right place to
implement one of these systems because you have enough ridership and therefore you can get the costs down when you utilize it the other element of driving
down the cost in the case of the Hyperloop is to make the system autonomous and the reason for that is
with autonomy you can get an optimization in terms of capacity of pushing people back and forth and then you have reduced operational costs
because you don't have to have something driving the vehicle and at the speed at which a Hyperloop can go which is in
excess of airline speeds you can't have a person with reaction time operating that system so you may have an operator
in the loop but they would be there for safety purposes but their driving has to be done autonomously the good news is
that the automotive sector is already working on autonomous driving vehicles for use in dense urban environments
which happens to be the most challenging problem in autonomy and the reality is is that you could
take a lot of that work leverage it and put it into something like a Hyperloop system which is a very controlled
environment as you're inside of a vacuum tube and so therefore you can have a lot of your technology development and the
capital expenditure associated with that conducted by people like Google at wano for example right so you can see how
these systems can couple to other modes of transportation which then brings me to the next topic of my talk which is
urban air mobility so I worked for a Hyperloop company for a year and a half it was really fun exciting and I enjoyed
it but as I expanded my network of people in the space by attending conferences like this woman it's a mini go to
conferences I met other people in the space and I met a gentleman who asked me to start up a company with him which is
an urban air mobility company and I give you an example once again from science-fiction The Jetsons flying cars everybody knows that
terminology it's a misnomer it's not really the right term because there are
aircrafts are not cars and they're not going to driver on the road because it's a very different use case a very different engineering design but
nevertheless the company is used the country or the world is used to that term so this is the space but it largely
is an aircraft which has the ability to take off and land vertically and so for those of you who have ever been to Los
Angeles in the room people who've been to San Francisco Mumbai Bangalore Delhi
Kolkata these are cities who have a congestion like nothing else I can stir damn it's really nice from a from a
traffic congestion perspective it's not as bad as many places in the world so if you live in urban environments and you
want to be able to get around to suburban locations or rural locations if you wanted to do that much faster than
driving and a subway doesn't exist yet because either you can't afford one or it can't be built you can look at
another way of this which is basically taking to the sky and therefore you get rid of the congestion on the ground problem because you're operating in the
dimensions of airspace which is 3d so I'll show you a video of what an implementation of that might look like

so that is the video of our concept vehicle that we call mobi 1 my company
is called airspace experience Technologies and it's based in Detroit which is in the Midwest of the United
States and it's the automotive capital of the United States and some people called the automotive capital of the world because that's kind of where it
started but of course there's many car companies that exist all around the world so the solution here that shown in
that video is a lectric vertical takeoff and landing aircraft our design is a
tilt wing aircraft which means that it can take off and land vertically with the wings shown in the position here or
it can take off and land like a regular airplane using existing runways at either general aviation airports or at
commercial hubs and so by having the ability to take off and land vertically you can therefore land in dense urban
centers and you can use existing infrastructure such as rooftops which are already set up for this you per
deport locations that might be created the future or even parking lots which exist all around cities at least in the United States now something that people
don't realize if they don't work in the transportation space and if they're not a pilot like I'm a pilot as well I fly
for fun I'm a general aviation pilot which means I don't apply I don't people can't hire me to fly for them but I can fly my friends around and things like
that is that there are airports all over the United States called general aviation airports which are used by
people like me to fly for fun but they're not used by most people to fly and so when you look at the cost of infrastructure it turns out that
ground-based infrastructure is the highest cost so if you can make use of an existing infrastructure asset which
is an existing Airport which the government is already funding and it's paying people to operate it in the airspace around it you'd be crazy not to
use so one of the arguments for urban air mobility is to make use of that existing infrastructure because it's
already underutilized especially in the United States not so much in countries like India they don't have as dense of an general
aviation Airport network but they do exist and you could actually use instead parking lots and vertical takeoff and
landing locations so this urban air mobility use case is not intended to be long-range aircraft application it's
intended to be short-range application and the reason for that is that we want to make the vehicle electric so the only
way that we're going to kickstart a sustainable aviation industry by making it all-electric is if we can find use
cases where you can have an aircraft which operates just on battery so range is an issue for electric
vehicles as it would be for an electric air vehicle so the urban use case which we don't really need more than 100 miles
of range on one of these vehicles enables you to have a fully electric aircraft which can be charged using the
grid power which can come from renewables so this is the way you can kick-start sort of a low carbon footprint aviation solution now over
time as hydrogen fuel cells are developed for example you can imagine these aircraft doing regional flights
and over time if this industry really does take off pun intended there'll be more batteries that come out which are
better suited for aviation use higher energy density and you can get to longer and longer ranges so that's really the
argument behind this and that air has been use case and as a pilot and it's my
hobby it's kind of a shame of course to have an application that I do for fun which has the carbon footprint so I
would love to have an electric airplane so I can have a lower carbon footprint so as I showed you with the Hyperloop
scenario prototyping and testing as quickly as possible is the way to go and so here is an example of one of our
subscale aircraft flying in a Detroit City Airport where we're based

so one thing that people like to ask me about this is is this going to be a self flying airplane and so we are designing
these aircraft to be autonomous the ability to fly by themselves but there would still be a pilot in the loop there's several reasons for that one
obviously the regulatory space doesn't allow from not having a pilot in the loop and two it makes sense to you know
keep people as safe as possible and only when you felt completely comfortable that you wouldn't need a pilot and the public felt completely comfortable with
that would that ever go away but largely when you fly commercially when you fly above 18,000 feet when you fly IFR most
aircraft do have autopilot an autopilot is utilized for most of the phases of flight with the exception of takeoff in
the final approach so that's already done in terms of having the software control in the vehicle but of course you
still would have a pilot in the loop so that's just something to give you a comfort on that level now the other issue of course you're probably all
thinking is that well helicopters are quite noisy this is not a helicopter this is not a rotor craft it's an
aircraft but having electric motors and having a more efficient system that we have here actually allows you to have
significantly lower noise levels so this would be two orders of magnitude less noisy than a helicopter for example so
more like a general aviation airports now I mentioned before but how do you lower the cost so anybody any pilots in
the room people fly for fun not so many and so aircraft are
notoriously expensive the reason for that is the production volumes for aircraft are incredibly low even for general aviation aircraft they're only
pushing out you know maybe at most a couple of hundred per year so cars on the other hand they're pushing out you
know how many cars come out on assembly line per day but it's quite a lot and so you get economies of scale with NASA
production both in terms of the techniques that are used to design and fabricate the vehicles as well as simply having many units allows you to lower
the cost per unit so if the urban air mobility space does take off you can actually lower the cost of the vehicle significantly to get it well below a
million dollars and because it's actually electric lowers the cost of operating on these vehicles so this
actually helps the whole aviation sector in general if you shift over to this electric vehicle because engine overhaul is the primary cost and maintaining an
aircraft and then something which I think is really interesting and something that we're thinking about and I encourage other people in the room to
think about is modifications and updates to air traffic control which largely also have the human beings in the loop
if you could use something like the b2x connected car network to be able to do traffic management and collision
avoidance because the aircraft are talking to each other you know they're you know positional space in time and
altitude and you know all three dimensions basically you can monitor traffic and manage traffic in that way
and that's something that I think people are open to updates in that area which is very much a software solution which
then comes to where everything is headed here is that many companies are starting to look as mobility as an end-to-end
service you know using public transportation getting scooters getting rideshare and then even potentially
getting aircraft so that's where this all couples very nicely to the software space because all of those solutions to
make it own demand require that integration and so whether we're talking about hyper loops electric cars or
electric aircraft whatever we can do to stop using internal combustion engines and jet engines and shift over to
electric vehicles does allow you to connect the planet in a sustainable way from that perspective so now just to do
a abrupt change where are we headed next we're actually headed next to space so
it maybe doesn't have as much coverage in the news here as it does the United States or perhaps it does I don't spend

Branson and these vehicles are both intended to give you access to suborbital travel primarily for the
purposes of tourism right now right so you get to see the arc of the planet from space you get to call yourself a
commercial astronaut and there are use cases where you can think about using this as traveling over distances for
really short speeds but largely their business case is based off of sort of a tourism aspect for people who are
interested not cheap of course so that doesn't couple to my prior slide about making it affordable and then there are
also companies working on the next thing which is sending people to low-earth orbit and beyond space travel so the
picture on the right is from SpaceX which of course is Elon Musk company this is the Dragon capsule
is already going back and forth to the International Space Station they want to make a red dragon version of this to be
able to send people to the moon and to Mars and the image on the left here is me in
front of the Orion capsule so this is a NASA funded program to send people beyond low-earth orbit basically lunar
applications asteroid retrieval mission applications and then of course sending people to Mars and even though it's a
government funded program the vehicle itself is designed developed fabricated and built in private industry so that
has always existed in the space program side of things so you can see that this sector is very interesting and there's a
lot of people in this space and there's also a lot of venture capital going into the space so it's definitely a market to
be considering in terms of your own companies that you may be working on so where are we headed to next after we
develop these vehicles it'll probably take us you know 10 to 15 years more in the testing space to get to the level
that we feel comfortable with using them but ultimately what we want to do what I want to do is to send people to Mars I'm
not as interested in the moon you can ask me questions about that if you want to later or this evening but I would like for us to go to Mars the reason for
that is not sort of a tourism journey but like setting up colonies there because if you're going to go anywhere
and our solar system Mars happens to be one of the most hospitable places
it isn't really but compared to the other ones it is in a sense that Mars does have a thin atmosphere which you
can utilize to sort of pressurize your habitats with co2 and grow plants in that co2 to create oxygen and then Mars
also has you know one third of the gravity so it's a little bit easier a body is then floating around in zero g
for example or even the 1/8 G of the moon and the radiation environment is somewhat attenuated by that atmosphere
and you can sort of put yourself under the ground to protect you so we have been to Mars several times as was the
introduction this is the program that I have worked on which is the Curiosity rover so the robotic space program is
the precursor of the technology development which then feeds forward to human exploration of Mars and so we've
got another Rover which is launching in 2020 in Europe as well as with ISA as
well as in 2020 with the human space program I had dinner with some of my ISA friends last night they were giving me
the latest and greatest on what's going on there and some of the other really important technologies
to enable the exploration of space do you come from sort of a much larger set
of technologies not just for space application one of course is artificial intelligence all of these environments
are very challenging in the human body so wherever you can use robots to do work for people either as partners or
before you actually get there it makes a lot of sense and so NASA does spend a lot of time developing robots to do
different tasks let's say for the space station the example Robonaut actually was opera and the space station it can
work in an operate in the vacuum environment and here's one which is a more mobile solution for work on the surface of Mars and so all of these
technologies can be developed in other spaces for other applications but can also be used for the space program so
it's nice to see these kind of synergies going on between those two areas so what
I do think is interesting and it does tie in nicely with sustainability is that in order for human beings to be
able to survive on Mars we really have to learn to be sustainable here at home first otherwise there's no way that
we'll survive going out to another planet and there's the ways that you do it on Mars is to generate your own power
if you're not limited to a small robotic platform like the Curiosity rover and you can actually set up a colony you can
set up large areas where you have solar panels for example right so you can take use of the solar energy come from the
Sun over a huge farm to generate power on Mars so one might ask why are we not
doing that more here we should be right so I think the one thing that we have no shortage if you're on planet earth is
space in an atmosphere which we're obviously polluting by not using things like solar panels a bit more but
generating your own power is a way that you could become self-sufficient here on earth as well as self-sufficient on Mars
the other one which we don't have to deal with here on earth is radiation protection because we have a very thick atmosphere and we have a magnetic field
that actually protects us from the high-energy particles that are coming from space on Mars this is actually a challenge because you are getting some
radiation from the Sun as well you're getting a lot of radiation from deep space which happens to be really high-energy and will basically cause
cancer if you don't do something to protect yourself against it so when you're living on the surface for an extended period of time that has to be
mitigated the good news is that we now have a reading of what that radiation level is from the Curiosity rover so now
we can design a shielding technology solution to mitigate that radiation so once you know
the sort of like the amplitude and the frequency space of energy then you can actually design a shield to protect you
from it and the good news on Mars is that you can be once again self-sufficient by creating subterranean
habitats or even structures out of Martian soil to make bricks to protect you from that water this is another
really important one it is an abundant resource here but we're also that's also
a challenge as well as the climate changes so we do need to address that and on Mars there's water frozen in the subsurface you can imagine actually
utilizing that to move your to basically convert it into oxygen and hydrogen
which can be fuel and then of course for eating and for washing and for all the other needs that people need water
another aspect of sustainability on Mars is methane you could actually create your own rocket fuel so that you can get
back to earth because no one's going to live there you know forever they will still have the ability to go back and forth and then another really
important one is extremophiles which are plants which have the ability to grow
with very little oxygen lots of co2 and as a result they produce oxygen from
this photosynthetic process and so admittedly that was a genetically engineering plant I know that's not popular in Europe but if you're going to
Mars you probably are going to want to do something on that front just so you can get enough food volume to keep people going so that kind of leads me to
my last question which is would you want to live on Mars so I think it's probably gonna happen the first people will
probably go there in let's say 15 years I think certainly in all of our lifetimes we will go there will there be
a colony in all of our lifetimes probably not but what I say in the next hundred years or so would things be
setting up there I think so because I think there's enough of an interest now especially from the business community side to be able to support those kinds
of developments moving forward and so even though these are all different transportation technologies whether it's
the Hyperloop whether it's urban air taxis whether it's launch vehicles or reentry vehicles they all use the same
principles of aerodynamics of control and of designing a set of requirements
based off of what your customers need so to wrap up I have I think five or ten
